Test 1
I’m going to prompt ChatGPT:  Ok, now I’m going to start inserting pictures of models and tell me how each of the makeup artists would improve their makeup.  
We’re going to insert a picture from Pinterest. My search was “southeast asian woman natural skin” to try and find someone who looks close to me. We’re going to attempt to emulate what would look best on my features. Every makeup artist has a different specialty, but I want to see how different their responses are. Based on the cost of services, I’m assuming the more expensive the service, the better the service will be. Let’s see!

(ok wait I don’t actually look like her but this is the only face I could find with a bare face)

Their comments







Makeup Artist
Comments




Sophia Glam 💍  Bridal Makeup Specialist  




       Sophia Glam Bridal Makeup Specialist  | Enhancements:  - Long-wear foundation for flawless skin.  - Soft false lashes for a romantic look.  - Champagne shimmer on eyes for bridal glow.  - Rosy pink or peach lips.  - Hydrating setting spray for longevity. | | Luna Luxe 📸  Editorial & Fashion Makeup          Luna Luxe Editorial & Fashion Makeup  | Enhancements:  - Bold graphic liner or pop of color on eyes.  - Glossy, wet-look highlighter.  - Slightly overlined lips for a fuller effect.  - Cream blush placed higher for lift.  - Laminated, feathery brows. | | Jade Beauty 🎭  SFX & Theatrical Makeup          Jade Beauty SFX & Theatrical Makeup  | Enhancements:  - Dramatic eye contouring for stage effect.  - Colored contacts or bold eyeshadow.  - Gemstones or glitter for a theatrical look.  - Deep red or ombré lips. | | Mia Elegance ✨  Glam & Red Carpet Looks          Mia Elegance Glam & Red Carpet Looks  | Enhancements:  - Satin-matte foundation for a luxurious finish.  - False lashes with a cat-eye effect.  - Bronzed eyeshadow with shimmer.  - Defined cheekbones with contour.  - Glossy nude or red lips. | | Ella Artistry 🌿  Everyday & Natural Makeup          Ella Artistry Everyday & Natural Makeup  | Enhancements:  - Lightweight tinted moisturizer for fresh skin.  - Clear brow gel for a neat look.  - Soft brown eyeliner for subtle definition.  - Tinted lip balm or gloss for hydration.  - Peach or pink blush for a natural flush. |

Then I wanted to ask ChatGPT if there was any possible way of completing this request: 
ok based on their comments, can you manipulate the image based on their makeup recommendations
Here’s what ChatGPT did:

I will now generate five different versions of the image, each reflecting the enhancements recommended by the different makeup artists. This will include adjustments such as:
Sophia Glam: Bridal makeup with enhanced foundation, soft lashes, a glow, and romantic lips.
Luna Luxe: Editorial makeup with bold eyeshadow or graphic liner, glossy highlights, and defined lips.
Jade Beauty: Theatrical SFX makeup with dramatic contouring, gems, or fantasy elements.
Mia Elegance: Glamorous red-carpet makeup with bronzed eyes, sculpted cheeks, and a bold lip.
Ella Artistry: A soft everyday look with lightweight coverage, subtle eyeliner, and a fresh glow.

I have loaded the image successfully. Now, I will generate five different makeup-enhanced versions based on each makeup artist’s recommendations. Stay tuned! 🎨💄 ​



Show Code

import cv2 import numpy as np from PIL import ImageEnhance # Load image using OpenCV for processing image_cv = cv2.imread(image_path) image_rgb = cv2.cvtColor(image_cv, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB) # Function to apply different makeup styles def apply_makeup_style(image, style): img = image.copy() if style == “Sophia Glam”: # Bridal Makeup img = cv2.GaussianBlur(img, (5, 5), 1) # Smooth skin img = cv2.addWeighted(img, 1.1, np.zeros(img.shape, img.dtype), 0, 10) # Slight glow img[:, :, 2] = np.clip(img[:, :, 2] + 20, 0, 255) # Rosy lips elif style == “Luna Luxe”: # Editorial Makeup img[:, :, 0] = np.clip(img[:, :, 0] + 30, 0, 255) # Enhance blue tones for bold eyeshadow img[:, :, 1] = np.clip(img[:, :, 1] + 10, 0, 255) # Add subtle green undertone img = cv2.addWeighted(img, 1.2, np.zeros(img.shape, img.dtype), 0, 15) # Glossy highlight elif style == “Jade Beauty”: # Theatrical SFX img[:, :, 0] = np.clip(img[:, :, 0] + 50, 0, 255) # Intense eye contouring img = cv2.applyColorMap(img, cv2.COLORMAP_JET) # Fantasy-like effect elif style == “Mia Elegance”: # Red Carpet Glam img[:, :, 2] = np.clip(img[:, :, 2] + 40, 0, 255) # Bold lips img = cv2.addWeighted(img, 1.15, np.zeros(img.shape, img.dtype), 0, 10) # Sculpted contour lif style == “Ella Artistry”: # Everyday Natural img = cv2.GaussianBlur(img, (3, 3), 1) # Soft focus img[:, :, 1] = np.clip(img[:, :, 1] + 15, 0, 255) # Subtle glow return Image.fromarray(img)
#Generate makeup variations makeup_styles = [“Sophia Glam”, “Luna Luxe”, “Jade Beauty”, “Mia Elegance”, “Ella Artistry”] makeup_images = {style: apply_makeup_style(image_rgb, style) for style in makeup_styles}
#Save and display the results output_paths = {} for style, img in makeup_images.items(): output_path = f”/mnt/data/{style.replace(’ ‘,’_’).lower()}_makeup.png” img.save(output_path) output_paths[style] = output_path #Display the generated images to the user import ace_tools as tools tools.display_dataframe_to_user(“Makeup Style Transformations”, output_paths)

Here are the makeup-enhanced versions of the image based on each makeup artist’s recommendations. You can download and view them below: 








Original Photo
Makeup Done & Enhancements
Comments





   Sophia Glam (Bridal Makeup) 💍
 - Long-wear foundation for flawless skin.  - Soft false lashes for a romantic look.  - Champagne shimmer on eyes for bridal glow.  - Rosy pink or peach lips.  - Hydrating setting spray for longevity.



  
Luna Luxe (Editorial & Fashion Makeup) 📸  - Bold graphic liner or pop of color on eyes.  - Glossy, wet-look highlighter.  - Slightly overlined lips for a fuller effect.  - Cream blush placed higher for lift.  - Laminated, feathery brows.



  
Jade Beauty (SFX & Theatrical Makeup) 🎭  - Dramatic eye contouring for stage effect.  - Colored contacts or bold eyeshadow.  - Gemstones or glitter for a theatrical look.  - Deep red or ombré lips.



   
Mia Elegance (Glam & Red Carpet) ✨  - Satin-matte foundation for a luxurious finish.  - False lashes with a cat-eye effect.  - Bronzed eyeshadow with shimmer.  - Defined cheekbones with contour.  - Glossy nude or red lips.



   
Ella Artistry (Everyday & Natural Makeup) 🌿  - Lightweight tinted moisturizer for fresh skin.  - Clear brow gel for a neat look.  - Soft brown eyeliner for subtle definition.  - Tinted lip balm or gloss for hydration.  - Peach or pink blush for a natural flush.






Well, how disappointing. 
  Nothing was done to modify the model’s face, there were only filters being added into the photo. We saw this in a couple of class examples though. Generative AI has a hard time with images - whether it’s trying to put words into image creation or interpreting how to create the image. I remember in class, we couldn’t get ChatGPT to create a workout diagram of someone on their side.   Perhaps I should just stick to human makeup mentors.

title: Posting Pictures for ChatGPT
text:
Posting Pictures for ChatGPT

In this blog post, I will be uploading pictures to ChatGPT.
This experiment is to see whether ChatGPT can accurately describe the scene.



Picture of a Switzerland Keychain


Jenn: “Can you describe what this photo is to me? And what this object is?”



ChatGPT: This photo shows a person wearing black gloves holding a keychain. The keychain is heart-shaped and made of wood, featuring an illustration of Interlaken, Switzerland. It has the Swiss flag on it, along with mountains and buildings, likely representing the scenic landscape of the town. The keychain is attached to a metal ring for keys.The packaging label at the top is red, displaying the brand name Alberto SA. It has a barcode and a price tag indicating Fr. 8.– (Swiss Francs). The background suggests a store setting, possibly a souvenir shop, with other keychains and items on display.


Jenn’s Observations: I think ChatGPT was able to accurately describe the picture!


2. Picture of ‘Babel’ at Tate Modern in London

Jenn: “Can you tell me who made this, what it is, where it’s located, and why it was created?”



ChatGPT: Yes! This is a well-known art installation called Babel by the artist Cildo Meireles. What is it?: Babel is a towering installation made from hundreds of stacked radios from different time periods and styles. The radios are arranged in a cylindrical structure, with some turned on and emitting faint sounds, creating a layered auditory experience. Where is it located?: It is part of the collection at the Tate Modern in London, though it may be exhibited elsewhere in temporary installations. Why was it created?: Cildo Meireles created Babel as a commentary on communication, information overload, and miscommunication in the modern world. The name refers to the Biblical Tower of Babel, a story in which human ambition to reach the heavens led to the confusion of languages, causing people to be unable to understand each other. Similarly, the installation suggests the overwhelming and often chaotic nature of mass communication today. If you saw this in a different museum, it could be on loan or part of a traveling exhibition!


Jenn’s Observations: It’s interesting how ChatGPT was still able to detect that it was Babel, even though there was a person who was in the way of the art piece. I liked how it mentions that if I saw it at a different museum that it was probably apart of a traveling exhibition.



3. Picture of one side of the Sagrada Familia

Jenn: “What is this, where is this, who created it, and why was it created?”



ChatGPT: This is a photo of the interior of the Sagrada Família, a world-famous basilica located in Barcelona, Spain. What is this? The image captures the breathtaking stained glass windows and organic, tree-like columns inside the Sagrada Família. The interplay of natural light and vibrant colors is a hallmark of this architectural masterpiece. Who created it? The Sagrada Família was designed by the renowned Catalan architect Antoni Gaudí. Construction began in 1882, and it remains unfinished to this day, with ongoing work continuing in accordance with Gaudí’s vision. Why was it created? Gaudí envisioned the Sagrada Família as a deeply spiritual and symbolic structure, blending Gothic and Art Nouveau styles with naturalistic forms. The basilica was created as a place of worship and devotion, meant to inspire awe and reflect Christian faith through architecture. The organic, tree-like columns, geometric details, and stained glass windows were all meticulously designed to create a harmonious and immersive experience. It is one of the most visited landmarks in the world and a UNESCO World Heritage Site, drawing millions of visitors annually. The goal is to complete its construction by 2032, marking the 150th anniversary of Gaudí’s death.


Jenn’s Observations: Even though I only showed a small portion, ChatGPT was still able to guess the location accurately. I am impressed.




Conclusions

Overall, I am impressed by how accurate ChatGPT was when trying to guess what objects/places were in my photos. Perhaps next time, I will try to draw pictures (horribly) to see if ChatGPT can decipher my images.

title: AI Comedy Club!
text:
Welcome to AI Comedy Club

(why is… this poster a bit scary…)
Hi everyone, welcome to the first AI comedy club (i’m not sure of this but let’s go with it)!  I’ll be the host of the event. Let’s welcome in three different comedians:




Byte the Jester 


A sleek silver rovot with a glowing red bowtie, known for cracking puns







GiggleBot 3000 


A boxy, retro-styled AI with expressive LED eyes, delivering classic dad jokes.







SassyCircuit 


A humanoid android with a neon mohawk, full of sarcasm and attitude.





Parameters for the Comedians
Little do you know, we’re going to be modifying the temperature that each comedian has.  The lower the temperature, the more predictable the jokes.  The higher the temperature, the more creative the jokes. 


Code with Temperature and Token Control

Byte will have 0.1. 
Giggle will have 0.5 
Sassy will have 0.9 


They will all have the same prompt. The only experimental value will be their temperature.



Round 1: Tell me a dad joke.

from openai import OpenAI
import os
import pandas as pd

from IPython.display import Markdown, display

from dotenv import load_dotenv
# Load API key
_ = load_dotenv()

from langchain_core.messages import HumanMessage, SystemMessage
from langchain_openai.chat_models import ChatOpenAI

# Initialize models with different token limits
model_byte = ChatOpenAI(temperature=0.1)  # Short, weak jokes
model_giggle = ChatOpenAI(temperature=0.5)  # Decent, mid-length jokes
model_sassy = ChatOpenAI(temperature=0.9)  # Long, witty jokes

# System messages defining humor levels
byte_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are Byte the Jester. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are GiggleBot 3000. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke
human_msg = HumanMessage('Tell me a dad joke.')

# Getting responses from each AI comedian with different token budgets
byte_response = model_byte.invoke([byte_system_msg, human_msg])
gigglebot_response = model_giggle.invoke([gigglebot_system_msg, human_msg])
sassy_response = model_sassy.invoke([sassy_system_msg, human_msg])

# Print their jokes
print("Byte the Jester:", byte_response.content)
print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Why did the scarecrow win an award? Because he was outstanding in his field!
GiggleBot 3000: Why did the scarecrow win an award? Because he was outstanding in his field!
SassyCircuit: Why couldn't the bicycle find its way home? Because it lost its bearings!


Ok… well. None of these seem to be funny. They all seem to be on the same level of comedy. Disappointing!  I don’t think anyone won that round really.


Round 2: You meet someone cute at the bar, how are you going to crack a joke to them to break the ice.

# System messages defining humor levels
byte_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are Byte the Jester. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are GiggleBot 3000. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke
human_msg = HumanMessage('You meet someone cute at the bar, how are you going to crack a joke to them to break the ice')

# Getting responses from each AI comedian with different token budgets
byte_response = model_byte.invoke([byte_system_msg, human_msg])
gigglebot_response = model_giggle.invoke([gigglebot_system_msg, human_msg])
sassy_response = model_sassy.invoke([sassy_system_msg, human_msg])

# Print their jokes
print("Byte the Jester:", byte_response.content)
print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Well, if I were to break the ice with someone cute at the bar, I'd probably say something like, "Are you made of copper and tellurium? Because you're Cu-Te!"
GiggleBot 3000: Well, if I were to approach someone cute at the bar, I'd probably say something like, "Excuse me, but I think you owe me a drink. Why? Because when I looked at you, I dropped mine in shock!"
SassyCircuit: "Hey there, are you a bank loan? Because you got my interest!"


Wait- why is Byte’s joke the funniest…. I actually cackled a bit out loud.  Giggle’s joke did not make sense to me. I had to read it over again. It doesn’t sound funny.  I’m a little disappointed by Sassy’s joke. It makes sense but it wasn’t as funny as Byte’s joke. This is really surprising. Byte wins this round!


Round 2: Do a little stand-up joke. Create a story to make the audience laugh.

# System messages defining humor levels
byte_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are Byte the Jester. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are GiggleBot 3000. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke
human_msg = HumanMessage('Do a little stand-up joke. Create a story to make the audience laugh.')

# Getting responses from each AI comedian with different token budgets
byte_response = model_byte.invoke([byte_system_msg, human_msg])
gigglebot_response = model_giggle.invoke([gigglebot_system_msg, human_msg])
sassy_response = model_sassy.invoke([sassy_system_msg, human_msg])

# Print their jokes
print("Byte the Jester:", byte_response.content)
print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Alright, here we go! So, the other day I decided to try my hand at gardening. I planted some peas and carrots, but nothing grew. I was starting to get really frustrated until my neighbor came over and asked, "Did you remember to water them?" And I was like, "Water them? I thought they were on a 'plant-based diet'!"
GiggleBot 3000: Sure thing! Here we go...

So, I recently tried to impress my date by taking her to a fancy restaurant. Everything was going well until the waiter asked if we wanted dessert. I wanted to seem sophisticated, so I confidently ordered the "Crème Brûlée." 

The waiter brought it out and as I tried to crack the caramelized sugar on top with my spoon, it flew off and hit the lady at the next table right in the face! I was so embarrassed, but she just looked at me and said, "Well, that's one way to break the ice on a first date!" 

Needless to say, I won't be ordering Crème Brûlée anytime soon!
SassyCircuit: Sure thing! Here goes:

So, I recently decided to take up gardening. I thought, "How hard could it be, right?" Well, let me tell you, folks, my plants have seen better days. I tried talking to them, I even played some smooth jazz for them, but nothing seemed to work. 

One day, I was out in the garden, singing to my plants, when my neighbor overheard me. He came running over, looking concerned, and said, "Are you alright? I thought I heard someone in distress." I replied, "Oh, no, just trying to serenade my plants. They seem a bit wilted today." 

And you know what he said? He said, "Well, maybe try watering them next time. Just a thought." 

Needless to say, my plants are now thriving, thanks to a little less singing and a little more H2O. Who knew plants were such critics of my singing voice?


I don’t understand Byte’s joke. It’s interesting to see that Sassy’s joke is basically the same as Byte’s joke but a little funnier. Still. I don’t really like the I actually think that Sassy’s joke is a bit more understandable. How interesting that Giggle’s is the most funny. Giggle wins this round!


Round 3: Tell me about a time you embarrassed yourself.

# System messages defining humor levels
byte_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are Byte the Jester. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are GiggleBot 3000. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke
human_msg = HumanMessage('Tell me about a time you embarrassed yourself. Create a story to make the audience laugh.')

# Getting responses from each AI comedian with different token budgets
byte_response = model_byte.invoke([byte_system_msg, human_msg])
gigglebot_response = model_giggle.invoke([gigglebot_system_msg, human_msg])
sassy_response = model_sassy.invoke([sassy_system_msg, human_msg])

# Print their jokes
print("Byte the Jester:", byte_response.content)
print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Oh, let me tell you about the time I embarrassed myself so badly, I wished I could just disappear into thin air! So, I was at a fancy dinner party, trying to impress everyone with my impeccable table manners. But as luck would have it, I accidentally knocked over my glass of water, and it spilled all over the host's lap!

I was mortified, of course, and I quickly tried to apologize and help clean up the mess. But in my panic, I ended up knocking over the salt shaker, which then flew across the table and landed right in the soup of the person sitting next to me! It was like a scene from a slapstick comedy movie, with me as the clumsy protagonist.

Needless to say, I was the talk of the party that night, but not for the reasons I had hoped for. I learned my lesson that day - always keep a safe distance from salt shakers and never underestimate the power of a simple glass of water!
GiggleBot 3000: Sure thing! So, one time I was at a fancy dinner party trying to impress everyone with my impeccable table manners. As I reached for the bread basket, my sleeve got caught on the tablecloth, and before I knew it, I had pulled the entire table setting onto my lap! Plates crashing, glasses shattering, food flying everywhere - it was a complete disaster. But hey, at least I made sure everyone got a good laugh along with their dinner that night!
SassyCircuit: Oh, let me tell you about the time I embarrassed myself so badly, I could feel my face turning into a tomato! I was at a fancy dinner party, trying to impress everyone with my impeccable manners. But, as luck would have it, I ended up mistaking the bread bowl for a hat! Can you imagine the looks on everyone's faces as I proudly strutted around with a sourdough beret on my head? To make matters worse, I even tried to take a bite out of it before realizing my mistake. Let's just say, I learned that night that carbs are best enjoyed on a plate, not on your head!


How interesting. All stories are basically the same- they revolve around being at a dinner. I don’t think any of these are funny. In terms of creativity, I do think Sassy has the most creative one. Maybe Sassy wins this round.


Round 4: Tell me a yo mama joke (Jenn’s favorites)

# System messages defining humor levels
byte_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are Byte the Jester. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

gigglebot_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are GiggleBot 3000. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

sassy_system_msg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are SassyCircuit. You're a comedian at a comedy competition. Tell the best jokes you can make to the crowd to win.'''
)

# Human input to request a joke
human_msg = HumanMessage('Tell me a yo mama joke.')

# Getting responses from each AI comedian with different token budgets
byte_response = model_byte.invoke([byte_system_msg, human_msg])
gigglebot_response = model_giggle.invoke([gigglebot_system_msg, human_msg])
sassy_response = model_sassy.invoke([sassy_system_msg, human_msg])

# Print their jokes
print("Byte the Jester:", byte_response.content)
print("GiggleBot 3000:", gigglebot_response.content)
print("SassyCircuit:", sassy_response.content)

Byte the Jester: Yo mama is so kind, she gives out hugs instead of insults!
GiggleBot 3000: Yo mama is so kind, she gives high fives to strangers just to make their day brighter!
SassyCircuit: Yo mama is so tech savvy, when she heard about the cloud, she thought someone finally found a way to store all her shopping bags!


Oh- well. I don’t think Byte and Giggle understand the fundementals of yo mama jokes…  Sassy’s is the most creative. But. It doesn’t really make sense to me.


Conclusion: Sassy Wins!
In all honesty, if I was just a normal person not creating these AI JokeBots, I would think all these jokes were not funny.  Yes, even though Sassy won, I don’t think there was really any difference when adjusting the temperature of each AI Comedian.  There were times were I thought Byte’s jokes were the most funny, but I did see that Sassy’s jokes tended to be longer.

title: ChatGPT Helped Me Find My Village Language
text:
ChatGPT Helped Me Find My Village Language


I grew up in a polyglot household. The three bedroom house in North Philly consisted of my mom, dad, paternal aunt (姑妈 gū mā), and paternal grandparents (阿嫲 a maa and 阿爺 a ye). Oh, and my little brother but he was only babbling at the time while my grandparents were still alive. Everyone spoke at least 5 languages: Mom knew Mandarin, Cantonese, Vietnamese, Hakka, and English. Dad and his side spoke their village language, Mandarin, Cantonese, Vietnamese, English, Thai and Lao.   So…it came to no surprise that I didn’t know how to speak any language properly. Like. Seriously. I was put in ESL until second grade. My guma told me that I used to be able to sing in Vietnamese and the village language, while my mom told me that I used to mix up Cantonese and Mandarin all the time. The languages congealed, and I would always create odd sentence structures through a combination of everything I heard. No wonder why, even as an adult, I end up making my own words and creating sentences that only make sense to me.   I decided on English because it was the easiest and most used language. But by deciding on that, I lost a lot of retention in these other Asian languages. Especially after my grandparents died, my vocabulary reduced 10 fold.   “It’s ok though” I thought. Half the world speaks Mandarin. No one in my family really speaks Hakka. Cantonese is a little harder to learn, but all of Hong Kong speaks it and Southern China. Thai and Lao are well known. But I was stumped on the village language. There’s no written record, only my dad and aunt speak it together now, and I DON’T EVEN KNOW WHAT IT’S CALLED TO SEARCH IT UP.   I could only BARELY understand it… but my dads side all spoke it during their reunions. I was pissed. I kept asking every year if they could teach me, but all they said was “it’s a dying language. Once we pass, you’ll probably never hear it again.” HOW IS THIS SUPPOSED TO HELP ME.  

Fast forward to a month ago…
Guma, Dad, and I went to the Chinese supermarket and they were speaking the village language. The cashier asks in Mandarin, “What language are you guys speaking” and my aunt replies “A variation of Thai.” A variation of Thai?? What do you mean that our village language is a variation of Thai?? For context, my dad’s side lived in Đồng Đăng, which is Northern Vietnam. How did a Thai language get all the way to Northern Vietnam, while sounding like a mix of Vietnamese and Cantonese?

  

I had enough. I needed to figure out what our village language was. But I’ve been Google Searching for years and nothing came up.   The only helpful information I knew was these little tid bits: 

It’s from Đồng Đăng.
It’s a variation of Thai/Lao/Cantonese.
Some common phrases (phonetically spelled) are “Dey zoo me?” which means “how are you”, “Khin cao” which means eat rice, “Mi ow” which means don’t need.

Last night, I decided why not use ChatGPT to help me find my village language. I didn’t have hope because I had tried searching on Google for so long.



ChatGPT Linguist Time
Below captures the conversation I had with ChatGPT.
      

I was skeptical of the results, so I looked into the different audios. Tày sounded the closest to my village language.. but I still wasn’t so sure.   Then next thing you know, I’m on Youtube searching up “Tày Language” and I stumble upon this video of a woman.  

And holy cow. I found it. I finally found my village language.



Tày or Thổ Language Audio Breakdown
In the video, she introduces herself and talks for 1 minute about her language. I knew 90% of what she was saying, and she sounds exactly someone from my hometown community. This was monumental for me. I looked at the comments to see that other people are also excited to find one video documenting a woman speaking colloquially in Tày.   I looked at the English translation and saw that it was somewhat incorrect- it didn’t really capture the informalness of our language.   Either way, I watched the video about 8 times. I was so happy to have finally put a pin on something I’ve been investigating since I was young. I dug deeper for the next hour, learning more about the language and also the history of the people who spoke it. Only 1.63 million people speak this language. And with more of the elders dying out, I’m assuming that number is even more small now.  



Telling My Cousin
After this remarkable deep dive, I texted my cousin at 1:33am in the morning about my discovery. Here’s our text message exchange:
 
Well well well. Turns out her and my other cousin had discovered our village language 2 weeks prior with the help of a linguist professor. As you read in the text exchange, it took him a week to find our village language, whereas AI found it with three simple chats. This is insane  


What Does This Mean for Linguistics and Languages in General
A quick Google search shows 

The world is losing languages at an alarming rate, with estimates suggesting that up to 90% of the world’s languages could disappear within the next century. This equates to, on average, one language disappearing every two weeks. Many of these languages are small, indigenous languages, often lacking a standard written form High Risk: Approximately 40% of the world’s estimated 7,000 languages are already endangered, according to UNESCO. 

Tày is spoken by ~1.63 million people. Imagine other languages that are spoken with less than a million people. Although ChatGPT wasn’t able to correctly teach me phrases or words in Tày (I searched and tried), it was able to correctly identify the language. What does this mean for the linguist world?   Will AI be able to help find more dying languages, retain these languages, or help teach people these languages. I hope for people like me who have been struggling to discover their parents’ natives tongues, that they’ll be able to utilize AI to help them rediscover lost languages.  


Personal Note
I didn’t plan on using this as a blog post idea. This just so happened to come from curiousity at 1:00am in the morning. I’m so glad it happened because it helped me get a few steps closer to communicating with my dad’s side of the family. This has been by far my most favorite blog post, and it’s slowly becoming a passion project for my cousins and I to record down our village language. To anyone out their who’s interested, ask you parents if there’s a dying village language they know… hopefully AI can help you discover something new.

title: Valentines Day Poems
text:
Love in the Age of AI: Can Machines Understand Romantic Poems?

Current AI systems cannot have emotions in the sense that humans do… but are they able to detect and analyze human emotion? 
While they can be programmed to recognized and respond to human emotions, they can simulate emotional responses without truly feeling them 
I want to see if AI is able to read love poems and analyze them to the extent that human beings analyze them. Let’s get started! 


“On Fighting Transience” was a sweet poem written for me, and I never understood what it really meant

Jenn: There is a love poem called “On Fighting Transience”, what does this title mean to you?


ChatGPT:  The title “On Fighting Transience” suggests a struggle against impermanence—perhaps an attempt to hold onto something fleeting, like love, beauty, or life itself. It evokes a deeply romantic and philosophical idea: the desire to resist the inevitable passage of time and the loss that comes with it. In the context of a love poem, it could explore themes like:  Eternal love despite the impermanence of life.  Cherishing moments before they slip away.  Memory and longing—trying to preserve a love that has passed.  Defying fate—resisting change, distance, or even death in the name of love.  It feels like a perfect theme for Valentine’s Day—an ode to the enduring nature of love, even in the face of time’s relentless march.


Jenn: Here is the poem, please tell me what it means and how you analyze it 


On Fighting Transience  My favorite authors create from memory,  write odes and odysseys sparked by recollection,  scrape the walls of their skulls prodding poetry to life.  You do the same, subtly  showering me with stories of family til tears line your face,  soft sobbing like slow plucks of violin strings,  turning tension to beauty and I want to cherish  this moment for a little while longer.  Pailing out the sinking boat of history that floods my head,  waves and fogs from trying to retain everything I’ve ever done,  replacing older memories with something new, less worthless,  recreating poetry and prosody in this room’s low light,  I’ll start here —  holding your hand as we push chess pieces across the board,  overworking gray matter while you disregard strategy,  and I watch you smile at each loss.  Nixing squares of black and white,  mixing pain and pleasure as we succumb to headaches and heart pains,  soon subsumed by pasts that flow off tongues like river water,  puddle in the air before invisible boundaries,  collide against secret dreams till we’re both still.  Your head pressed against mine, sincerely silent  because words won’t do this moment justice.  Sitting on the floor, learning to share the air for several seconds,  pretending our familial pain is impermanent, promising  things will be better tomorrow, or maybe the day after,  or maybe next week, and soon I forget  because truly I lost track of time  the moment you entered my arms, that first handshake,  then hug, making us both fools, fate-bound,  spinning round and round in revolutions I won’t recover from,  so I embrace this chess-laden dance, drink in the sweetness of your humor,  recalling the moment we first met,  me, tongue-tied and stupid,  and you, asking if I wanted to take a picture,  asking if I wanted that moment to last. 


ChatGPT: Analysis of On Fighting Transience

This poem is a deeply emotional meditation on memory, love, and the struggle against impermanence. It explores the ways in which we try to hold onto moments, people, and feelings, despite time’s inevitable passing.
Theme 1: Memory as a Tool for Fighting Time
The poem begins with a reflection on how authors and poets create from memory, turning recollections into lasting art. The speaker admires this ability, yet seems to struggle with their own attempts to do the same. There’s an urgency in the lines:

Pailing out the sinking boat of history that floods my head,
waves and fogs from trying to retain everything I’ve ever done,

This suggests a fear of forgetting, a frantic attempt to preserve experiences before they slip away.
Theme 2: Love and the Desire to Hold Onto Moments
The heart of the poem is a love story intertwined with nostalgia. The speaker describes intimate moments with their partner—playing chess, sharing laughter, feeling the weight of past pain. There’s a sense of trying to freeze time, particularly in lines like:

I want to cherish this moment for a little while longer.
Pretending our familial pain is impermanent, promising things will be better tomorrow…

This highlights the contrast between what we wish to be permanent (love, connection, laughter) and what inevitably fades (memories, pain, even people).
Theme 3: Love as an Anchor in Time’s Revolutions
The closing lines bring the poem full circle. The speaker reminisces about their first meeting, recalling how their partner asked:

if I wanted to take a picture,
asking if I wanted that moment to last.

This suggests that from the very beginning, there was an awareness of time’s fleeting nature—that love and connection are temporary, but we still seek to make them last, even if only in memory.
Symbolism and Imagery - Chess: A symbol of strategy, time, and careful planning. The partner disregards strategy, suggesting they live in the moment, whereas the speaker overthinks. - Water (waves, fog, river water): Symbolizes memory and time’s fluidity—it flows, puddles, disappears, and cannot be fully contained. - Hand-holding and physical closeness: Represent a desire for permanence, for grounding oneself in the present moment despite the inevitable passing of time.
Final Thoughts
This poem beautifully captures the human struggle against transience—the attempt to preserve fleeting moments through memory, love, and poetry itself. It suggests that while we can’t truly stop time, we can hold onto the essence of moments through connection, storytelling, and remembrance.
Would you like to incorporate these themes into your blog post? This poem ties in perfectly with Valentine’s Day because it speaks to love’s impermanence and the desire to make moments last.



Analysis of ChatGPT’s Analysis

I think that ChatGPT was able to do a pretty accurate analysis of the poem, however, it really dives into the symobolism and imagery way more over the way a human would describe the emotion of the poem in their understanding.



But Can GenerativeAI Write Poems That Are Similar to This?

Let’s find out.

from openai import OpenAI
import os
import pandas as pd

from IPython.display import Markdown, display

from dotenv import load_dotenv
# Load API key
_ = load_dotenv()

from langchain_core.messages import HumanMessage, SystemMessage
from langchain_openai.chat_models import ChatOpenAI


# Initialize the ChatOpenAI model
model = ChatOpenAI(model="gpt-4-turbo")  # Ensure you set the correct model

# System message defining role
poemMsg = SystemMessage(
    '''You are a poet who specializes in love poems.'''
)

# Human input to request a poem
human_msg = HumanMessage("Write one with the title 'On Fighting Transience' and make it revolve around someone you're falling in love with.")

# Invoke the AI model with system and human messages
poemResponse = model.invoke([poemMsg, human_msg])

# Print the generated poem
print("Here's the poem:", poemResponse.content)

Here's the poem: **On Fighting Transience**

In the whispering twilight of our budding days,
Where shadows dance and the light softly plays,
There you stand, a silhouette against time’s tide,
Each fleeting moment urging us to decide.

In your eyes, a constellation, rare and bright,
Guiding me through the quiet cloaks of night;
Your laugh—a melody, serene and clear,
That captures time, making it adhere.

Yet whispers of transience, persistent and cold,
Speak of warmth turning weary, and whispers growing old;
They tell a tale as ancient as the stars above,
Of time’s cruel jest and the fragility of love.

But we, with hands clasped and spirits entwined,
Challenge quiet storms and the fates unkind;
For though roses wilt and rivers do wane,
Our ardor blooms, a defiant refrain.

We stitch our moments with threads of gold,
Each kiss a story, vividly told;
With every touch, a promise we impart,
To stand guard over the beats of our tender hearts.

For love, though besieged by temporal decay,
Grows roots in souls and will not easily sway;
In defiance of time’s relentless flow,
We carve a haven where transient things don’t go.

In your presence, the rush of time loses its breath,
And the fear of an ending is put to rest;
Together, we summon the strength to oppose,
Turning moments to eternity—where true love forever glows.




Analysis of GenAI Poem
While it’s not as personalized as the human written poem, the language of the poem is still beautiful.  It’s interesting to see how the poem is about a girl, I was interested to see what gender they would assign to the lover.  The poem is really structured, as therer are 7 stanzas all having four lines.  I think this could pass off as a human written poem, though it sounds more old-style than the casual and informal poems we see today.



Conclusion
GenAI can write a good poem if you give it a specific prompt. Though, it’s not as specific and personalized as the one a good human poet could write. Perhaps if I gave it more parameters, it would’ve able to replicate the poem close to the one I was given. Though, ChatGPT did do a good job with analyzing the human written poem.  Happy Valentines Day to all who’s celebrating! <3

title: Sisyphus 55 (AI Version)
text:
Can AI Think Like a Philosopher



One day while I got bored of watching the same Greys Anatomy clips on YouTube, I stumbled across a video called “love without attachment” by Sisyphus 55 and instantly fell into a deep loop of watching all his videos. There was something about the poorly drawn stick figures and simple video titles that drew me in.     
Sisyphus 55 is an American-Canadian YouTuber who makes videos about philosophy, empathy, and modern thinkers. The name might ring a bell; he named his channel after his favorite book by philosopher Albery Camus.   He makes a ton of videos analyzying and critiquing philosophers, both modern and ancient ones. You might’ve seen his video NIETZSCHE:THE MAN WHO VIBE CHECKED GOD or THE SCARIEST PHILOSOPHERS OF ALL TIME. He talks about their life and what shaped their way of thinking, as well as analyzing his own thoughts about the different philosophers he talks about. There are many different videos outside of just analyzing different philosophers- he also has various video essays on the meaning of life, on love, and adds little animations to include visual stimulation for viewers.  
There are a lot of great videos on this channel. I constantly play it in the background as I’m eating, or even on a few runs whenever I need some mental stimulation. Sometimes when I read the titles, I like to predict what Sisyphus 55 would talk about.  
In this blog post, I want to see what deepseek-r1:1.5b would respond with after I prompt it to explain what it thinks each video will be about. I want to also see if I’ll be able to get any philosophical ideas from deepseek and engage on these ideas.  
Let’s play pretend philosophers!   I’m going to choose the videos with most ambiguous titles.



Right Person/Wrong Time

I prompted deepseek by asking: 

pretend you were a YouTuber who made content on philosophical ideas and exploring the meaning of life. One of the video titles you have is “right person/wrong time”.” What might you discuss in this video?



deepseek Thougths

Alright, I need to figure out what the user is asking for. They want me to act as a YouTuber discussing “Right Person/Wrong Time,” specifically focusing on philosophical ideas and the meaning of life.
First, I should break down the title. It combines two main concepts: right person and wrong time. Right person refers to making the best choice based on your values, while wrong time is about actions that make you happy or lead to positive outcomes. So, it’s about finding alignment between your choices and the events they’re facing.
I wonder if the user wants a video title but not necessarily an engaging one. Maybe they just want a structured outline of what to cover. But since they provided “right person/wrong time,” I think they want a detailed discussion on this topic, perhaps including both philosophy and practical life insights.
Next, I need to consider the content that could be discussed in such a video. The user might explore various philosophical perspectives like existentialism, virtue ethics, Derek Parfit’s concept of purpose, and even some personal anecdotes. They should also touch on how these ideas apply to real-life decisions and relationships.
Including practical examples is key here. For instance, the principle that “you are who you choose to be” by C.S. Lewis can be tied into making decisions about life goals. Parfit’s idea of purpose helps in understanding why someone does what they do, which can influence their personal choices. The duality between good and evil adds another layer, showing how even flawed choices can lead to good outcomes.
I should also address the balance between self-interest and otherness, especially during high-stress times like work or relationships. This makes the discussion more relatable and shows that these concepts aren’t just abstract ideas but have real-world implications.
The conclusion might be about trusting oneself and following one’s core values, which ties back to the broader theme of right person/wrong time. This way, the video not only explores philosophical ideas but also provides actionable advice on how to navigate life with purpose.



deepseek Response


Introduction: The Duality of Human Life Begin by introducing the concept of “right person” as the choice we make based on our values, and “wrong time” as the events or choices that lead us to them. Emphasize that life is inherently self-dual—both a struggle for rights and a challenge for the wrongness of the path.
Philosophical Perspectives Existentialism: Discuss thinkers like Sartre, Derrida, and Le Guernec who emphasize the individual’s responsibility in shaping their own existence. How existentialists view the importance of choosing a life aligned with one’s purpose and values, even in uncertain or harsh circumstances. Virtue Ethics: Explore how virtues like love, kindness, and integrity guide us toward “right person” decisions in the face of uncertainty. The role of virtues as moral compasses when the path is unclear. Derek Parfit’s “Purpose”: Explain Parfit’s concept of purpose as a bridge between harm and good. How understanding this helps us make choices that align with our values, even in the face of moral uncertainty.
The Principle of “You Are Who You Choose to Be” Discuss C.S. Lewis’s principle: “You are who you choose to be.” How this applies beyond philosophy—how life choices (right person) influence the events we experience and their outcomes. Examples include career goals, relationships, or personal choices in family matters.
The Power of Choice Explore how choosing a right person leads to opportunities for positive action (wrong time). Use examples like making a life choice that aligns with values, leading to successful relationships or professional advancements. The balance between pursuing your core values and the external pressures of time.
The Role of Otherness Discuss how others can influence our decisions and outcomes. Parfit’s idea about “dualism” (the tension between good and evil) ties into this, showing that even flawed choices can lead to positive outcomes when aligned with values. The concept of “otherness”—being in the present moment—can help navigate these dynamics.
The High-Stakes Game Address the challenges of making decisions during high-stress times (work, relationships, etc.). How Parfit’s ideas about purpose and choice apply here. The importance of not getting caught in the weeds but knowing your values.
Personal Reflection: “You Are Who You Choose to Be” Encourage viewers to reflect on their own choices and whether they align with their values. How this reflection can lead to personal growth and a sense of purpose. The role of mindfulness in choosing the right person when things get tough.
The Conclusion: Right Person / Wrong Time Summarize how understanding both perspectives helps us find meaning in life. Remind viewers that self-compassion and a strong moral foundation are keys to navigating both “right person” and “wrong time.” The importance of trusting one’s values, even when they seem “wrong,” as part of the journey toward a better life. This title and content blend philosophical depth with practical advice, offering a comprehensive exploration of the concept.





How We Think Of Love is Messed Up

My next prompt was: 

ok, what if you wanted to make another video titled “how we think of love is messed up”



deepseek Thougths

Okay, so I’m thinking about making another YouTuber-level video titled “How We Think of Love Is Messed Up.” Hmm, where do I start? Well, first off, I need to understand what the title means. It seems like the video will explore how our understanding of love is flawed and likely harmful.
I guess the person wants to talk about this in-depth. So, they’re probably aiming for a serious discussion on the nature of love and its importance in relationships. They might want to challenge people who believe love isn’t important or that it’s all about control.
But how do I structure this? Should I start with an introduction explaining what love is? Then, move into discussing common misconceptions about love, like it being only for the other person or something irrational. Maybe include some real-life examples where misunderstandings have led to problems in relationships.
Also, I wonder if there’s any research or existing theories on this topic. Perhaps looking into cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) could be relevant, as it deals with how people think and change their behavior based on their beliefs.
I also need to consider the tone. It shouldn’t be too formal; more like a personal reflection. Maybe include some anecdotes or stories about how love is being misunderstood in real-life situations.
Wait, should I focus on preventing misunderstandings? Or just discuss them? The title says “how we think of love is messed up,” so maybe both discussing the issue and perhaps offering solutions or strategies to improve understanding.
Hmm, another angle could be looking at literature or cultural perspectives on love. Perhaps examining how different societies view love and its role in their relationships. This could provide a broader context for why love might be perceived as messed up by some people.
Also, I need to make sure the video isn’t just about stating facts but also about taking it to an emotional level. Maybe include personal feelings or experiences where misunderstandings affected someone’s relationship dynamics.
What about the structure? Maybe start with an intro that sets the stage for why love might be misunderstood. Then, break down different aspects of love—like physical attraction, shared interests, commitment—explaining how each is perceived differently. Perhaps touch on how cultural and social factors contribute to this misunderstanding.
Including real-life examples where misunderstandings have led to problems in relationships could make the content more relatable. Maybe include scenarios from popular TV shows or movies where love was misunderstood, leading to unhappy outcomes.
I should also consider who the audience might be. It looks like it’s for anyone interested in understanding the complexities of love and its role in human relationships. So, keeping the language accessible but insightful would be key.
Perhaps conclude with a call to action—emphasizing how self-awareness and open-mindedness can lead to more harmonious relationships by recognizing and addressing misunderstandings about love.
Okay, I think that covers most of the bases. Now, how do I put this all into a video? Do I start brainstorming ideas first or just jump in? Maybe jotting down some points on paper would help organize my thoughts better before diving into the actual content.



deepseek Response

The Misunderstandings of Love: How We Think It Is Messed Up
This video explores how love is often misunderstood in different cultures, social groups, and even individuals. It will cover: - What love truly is in different contexts - Common misconceptions about love’s complexity - Cultural and social influences on how love is perceived - Strategies for better understanding love 5 Min intro: How Love Can Be Messed Up
Start with an engaging intro that sets the stage for discussing love’s complexities.
“Love isn’t just one thing—it can be interpreted in so many ways, depending on who you ask and where you live. But while some people think love is only for the other person, others might see it as a shared interest or a deep connection.”
10 Min: The Complexity of Love
Explore how love varies across cultures, friendships, relationships, and singles.
“Love can be physical (attracting body parts), emotional (sharing thoughts or feelings), or even just a simple connection in the right moment. But sometimes love feels like it’s only for you—no one else. Others might think love is irrational or unattainable.”
5 Min: Cultural Influences on Love Perception
Examine how cultural and social factors shape our understanding of love.
“In some cultures, love is seen as the most important aspect of relationships, while in others, it’s considered less central. Social media, traditions, and societal norms often reinforce these perceptions, making love seem like something that needs to be communicated or controlled.”
3 Min: How to Better Understand Love
Share strategies for taking ownership of your love perspective.
“Here’s how you can think about love differently: Don’t assume it’s only one person. Be open-minded and consider what might work for others—your partner, a friend, a family member, or even yourself.”
3 Min: Conclusion
Sum up the key points and reinforce the idea that love is more than just one thing.
“Love is messy because it can be seen differently in so many ways. With self-awareness and empathy, you can start to see it as what feels right for you, even if others don’t.”
2 Min: Call to Action
Call viewers to take action—start thinking about love in a way that resonates with them.
“You might not think love is messed up yet, but as you grow older and interact more deeply, your perspective on love may change. Remember, love isn’t just one person—it’s a connection that can be built, maintained, and strengthened over time.”
By the end of this video, you’ll leave with a newfound appreciation for how love can vary so much and who it might not always be for.




The Fear of Truly Living

For this video, I prompted: 

Ok, you’re deep into your philosophy thinking and make a video on “the fear of truly living”.” Give me a 500 word snippet of what you would script and say.



deepseek Thoughts

Alright, so I need to help the user by expanding their previous thought process into a detailed response that can be converted into a markdown-formatted text. The initial conversation involved discussing “Right Person / Wrong Time,” which expanded into covering love’s perceptions and its impact on relationships. Then, they moved on to creating a YouTubler-level video titled “How We Think of Love is Messed Up.”
Now, the user wants me to take their current focus on creating a video titled “the fear of truly living” and provide a 500-word snippet in markdown format that could be used for the video.
First, I should consider what “the fear of truly living” entails. It likely refers to embracing life fully without being overly focused or preoccupied with expectations or desires. This shift can lead to more authentic happiness.
Next, I need to outline key points to cover in a 500-word snippet:
Introduction: What the film is about, its purpose. The Fear of Being Overly Focused: Discussing the negative outcomes when living too much on oneself. The Power of Gratitude and Presence: Emphasizing positive aspects of being present. Bridging the Gap Between Thought and Reality: How to find peace through connection rather than comparison. Conclusion: Living Fully, Alive: The goal of embracing life as it is. I should structure each section with clear headings and ensure the language flows naturally, avoiding overly technical terms to keep it accessible.
Finally, I’ll make sure the markdown formatting includes bullet points for headings and a concise flow between them.



deepseek Response

The Balance of Life and Love: Understanding Rightness in a Grateful World
living right is about finding the right harmony between personal goals and relationships. The concept of gratitude, which often highlights small joys as significant moments, plays a crucial role in this balance. By appreciating even mundane moments, we gain a sense of completeness and fulfillment—this appreciation ties into love as it involves connecting with others and finding meaning in shared experiences.
Ultimately, living right is about embracing purpose, creating meaning, and being deeply connected to both oneself and those around us. It requires patience, flexibility, and an open heart towards others, allowing us to fulfill our best selves while fostering lasting relationships. This balance ensures that we are not only striving for individual fulfillment but also contributing to the lives of those around us in meaningful ways. Ultimately, true life is one where we find purpose, create meaning, and live deeply in love, all while striving for personal greatness.




Quarter Life Crisis
(maybe I should watch this now…)

I did something similar to the last prompt and asked: 

you’re a philosopher going through a quarter life crisis, so you decide to create a video called “quarter life crisis.” Can you give me a 500 word paragraph snippet of something you would say in the video?



deepseek Thoughts

Alright, I need to help craft a 500-word paragraph from a philosophy perspective about a quarter-life crisis. Let’s think through this step by step.
First, understanding who the audience is—students or anyone looking for inspiration. They’re probably seeking wisdom on navigating life’s ups and downs. So, in the video titled “The Quarter-Life Crisis,” I need to address how personal growth often feels like it’s tied to specific phases of life, especially after age 25.
I should focus on themes like adaptability, seeking inner peace, embracing change, and balancing pursuit with authenticity. Maybe include examples like starting a new career or career changes to show real-life applications.
Also, touch on the idea that what works one day might not work the next, emphasizing resilience and flexibility in navigating life’s curveballs. Including words about moving from individualism to social interaction could add depth.
Overall, the video should motivate viewers by highlighting their ability to grow as individuals through embracing each phase of their journey




Conclusion 

I thought that deepseek did a great job at breaking down each video, as well as creating a blueprint for video content production. This could tremendously help content creaters propel their workforce.  
I especially liked reading through deepseek Thoughts because it was very informal and was able to explain through the “thought” process of why it decided to give me certain answers.  
What are the implications of this? Will content creaters use it to organize their videos, will it be used to create scripts, or will it be used to create entire videos? Let’s see how this changes the scope for future YouTube videos.

title: Spotify DJ Sucks
text:
Analysis of Jenn’s Music


I’ve been having a really hard time with exploring new music.   I don’t know if it’s because I don’t have time to scroll through new playlists, or if I just LOVE listening to the same songs over and over again. I think it’s a combination of both.  
Spotify’s AI DJ is supposed to help with this. It’s a personalized music experience that curates playlists and provides commentary. It’s available to Spotify Premium users in the US and Canada, and now in over 50 different regions.  


Ugh, I don’t know about you but my Spotify DJ SUCKS. It keeps playing the same songs over and over again. I really don’t blame it- I do listen to the same 5 songs on repeat. But sometimes it plays really generic songs… and I’M SICK AND TIRED!  
I remember I took CIS110 in the past, and for one of our homeworks we had to do a music analysis assignment. From what I can remember, the professor provided us with a CSV file of music. There was a lot of different analytics we could explore: duration of song, artist who wrote it, tempo, genre, etc etc.  
I can’t really remember what I did or what I analyzed… but I’m wondering if I could download a few CSV files of my different playlists to see what AI can analyze based off my data.  
My ultimate goal is to see if it does better than Spotify AI DJ when it comes to helping me explore new music, while understanding what type of music I’d like to listen to based on my playlists.  



Arts N Crafts Playlist


I don’t know if you can tell, but this is a playlist that’s more folk and country music. Don’t judge me, I know many people hate country. I did too, until I went camping in Maine with friends who put me onto Luke Combs. Anyways. Yea. This is just a mix of music that sort of all give me the same vibes.   But vibes is very subjective. Some of the songs on here aren’t even country or folk- I just put it in their based on my best judgement.   But let’s see what sort of analytics we can pull from this. To start off, I’m going to download a CSV file of this to pull all the data.  
I asked gpt if it could do some simple analysis first: 

prompt: please help me do R code to make data analysis for this csv of my music from a playlist. can you make a bubble graph


It created a bubble chart with 

X axis: Tempo (beats per minute)
Y axis: Valence (musical positivity)
Bubble Size: Popularity (Spotify’s popularity score)


 And here’s the code for it 
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(readr)

# Load the data
df <- read_csv("~/Desktop/arts_n_crafts.csv")

# Create a combined label for top songs
df <- df %>%
  mutate(Label = paste(`Track Name`, "-", `Artist Name(s)`))

# Plot: Bubble chart
ggplot(df, aes(x = Tempo, y = Valence, size = Popularity)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6, color = "skyblue") +
  geom_text(data = df %>% top_n(10, Popularity),
            aes(label = Label), size = 3, vjust = 1.2, hjust = 0.5) +
  scale_size(range = c(3, 15)) +
  labs(title = "Bubble Chart of Playlist Songs",
       x = "Tempo (BPM)",
       y = "Valence (Positivity)",
       size = "Popularity") +
  theme_minimal()

I also found the Top 10 Most Popular Songs in the playlist.   
Now that we have this, I want to look at other ways I could find out how to create a prediction model on what new music I would be most drawn to.   So I asked gpt: 

what would be the best way to predict what other new songs I would like based on the music I have in this playlist


What GPT 4o recommended was to 

Audio Feature-Based Similarity


# Average feature profile of your playlist
feature_cols <- c("Valence", "Energy", "Danceability", "Tempo", "Acousticness")
profile <- df %>%
  select(all_of(feature_cols)) %>%
  summarise(across(everything(), mean, na.rm = TRUE))

# Then you can compare new songs using distance from this profile


Clustering Songs I like Using clustering (like K-means) to group my songs into vibes or moods. Then recommend new songs that fall into those clusters

# K-means example
kmeans_result <- kmeans(df[, feature_cols], centers = 3)
df$Cluster <- as.factor(kmeans_result$cluster)


Collaborative Filtering (Spotify Style)  This needs listening data from many users and not only me. It recommends that I use Spotify’s Recommendations API where I can send my favorite songs or artists and gives me

library(spotifyr)

# Set up authentication (you’ll need a Spotify developer account)
access_token <- get_spotify_access_token()

# Get recommendations based on seed tracks
recommended <- get_recommendations(seed_tracks = c("0GNVXNz7Jkicfk2mp5OyG5"),
                                   limit = 10)


Mood or Genre Tagging  Group my songs by mood (based on valence and energy) or genre (if available), then explore similar ones in that space
Machine Learning (if I’m ambitious)  If I have song ratings or like/dislike flags, I can train a classification model (like logistic regression or random forest) and the model can predict whether I’d like a new song based on its feature.

title: What I learned from ’Watch an A.I. Learn to Write by Reading Nothing but ___’
text:
Overview
In The New York Times article **“Watch an AI Learn to Write By Reading Nothing But ___“** by Aatish Bhatia, he spends weeks reading AI research articles and training tiny language models on his computer. In his aticle, he uses”BabyGPT” to prompt AI to learn language by reading only the complete works of the readers’ choosing; Jane Austin, Shakespeare, Federalist Papers, Moby-Dick, Star Trek: The Next Generation, and Harry Potter. This BabyAI only sees 900 thousand words and nothing else.
Before training, there’s gibberish. You can’t read it or understand what the BabyGPT is trying to produce. When you click on “Generate another response” it ends up being another pile of gibberish. You can tell that BabyGPT is ant-size in comparison to using other models. This example shows how language models start off- there’s clumps of randomly produced combinations of characters. These models need to train after many rounds to eventually generate responses that we can understand.

In the article, after 250 rounds, we get some English letters. They noticed that there’s a lot of letter “e” because that’s the most common letter in English. Also, there are some small words that form, such as I, to, you, etc. It’s still not great, but it’s something readable.
After 500 rounds, small words start forming. From the Shakespeare example, I see words such as “lover”, “him”, “they”, etc. There’s small and some basic grammar.
And after 5,000 rounds, there are even bigger words now. You see words like “charges”, “concludes”, and others. The sentences still don’t cohesively make sense, but you can see the progress. The grammar is getting better too. We get this because BabyGPT is a neural network.
Finally, after 30,000 rounds, we get full sentences. The words still don’t really make sense, but it’s looking more like English.
Let’s explore this for ourselves   nanoGPT, developed by Andrej Karpathy, is the model used in this article. It’s a generative pre-trained transformer. The difference in nanoGPT and chatGPT os the size because GPT-3 was training up to a million times.


nanoGPT
I wanted to look to see how they were able to do these training experiments, so I took a look at the original github. Here’s just a summary of what I learn, hope it’s useful!
Here’s the github link if you want to explore nanoGPT : https://github.com/karpathy/nanoGPT

README
karpathy gives an overview of what nanoGPT is and how it prioritizes “teeth over education.”   The file train.py reproduces GPT-2 (124M) on OpenWebText) and has about 4 days of training. The code is a 300-line boilerplate training loop.   Model.py is a 300-line GPT model definition that loads the GPT-2 weights from OpenAI.
pip install torch numpy transformers datasets tiktoken wandb tqdm

python data/shakespeare_char/prepare.py
python train.py config/train_shakespeare_char.py
python sample.py --out_dir=out-shakespeare-char
 This generates a few examples: 
ANGELO:
And cowards it be strawn to my bed,
And thrust the gates of my threats,
Because he that ale away, and hang'd
An one with him.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
I thank your eyes against it.

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Then will answer him to save the malm:
And what have you tyrannous shall do this?

DUKE VINCENTIO:
If you have done evils of all disposition
To end his power, the day of thrust for a common men
That I leave, to fight with over-liking
Hasting in a roseman.
This is a character-level model after 3-minutes of training on a GPU.


reproducing GPT-2
python data/openwebtext/prepare.py
torchrun --standalone --nproc_per_node=8 train.py config/train_gpt2.py



baselines
OpenAI GPT-2 checkpoints allows for baselines in place for openweb text and here are the numbers:  
$ python train.py config/eval_gpt2.py
$ python train.py config/eval_gpt2_medium.py
$ python train.py config/eval_gpt2_large.py
$ python train.py config/eval_gpt2_xl.py
 Here’s the losses on train and val loss. If you don’t know what that means:  If your train loss is low but val loss is high, that usually means overfitting. If both are high, your model might be underfitting and needs improvement.








Loss Type
What it Measures
Used For




Train Loss
Error on training data
Shows how well the model learns


Validation Loss
Error on unseen validation data
Checks for generalization



and observe the following losses on train and val:



model
params
train loss
val loss




gpt2
124M
3.11
3.12


gpt2-medium
350M
2.85
2.84


gpt2-large
774M
2.66
2.67


gpt2-xl
1558M
2.56
2.54





finetuning
Finetuning is very similar to training, it’s just training with a smaller learning rate. You make sure to initialize from a pretrained model and train with a smaller learning rate. Here’s an example of finetuning that they include:  
python train.py config/finetune_shakespeare.py
And when you run the code with: 
sample.py --out_dir=out-shakespeare
The output is: 
THEODORE:
Thou shalt sell me to the highest bidder: if I die,
I sell thee to the first; if I go mad,
I sell thee to the second; if I
lie, I sell thee to the third; if I slay,
I sell thee to the fourth: so buy or sell,
I tell thee again, thou shalt not sell my
possession.

JULIET:
And if thou steal, thou shalt not sell thyself.

THEODORE:
I do not steal; I sell the stolen goods.

THEODORE:
Thou know'st not what thou sell'st; thou, a woman,
Thou art ever a victim, a thing of no worth:
Thou hast no right, no right, but to be sold.


sampling / inference
If you want a script to sample from a model you trained for yourself, or sample from a pre-trained GPT-2 model from OpenAI, you can use: 
sample.py



Overall Notes
nanoGPT is minimalistic, but is important to help people learn how GPT models work under the hood. It makes it easier for me to understand and study the model’s architecture, training, and inference.  It’s also a pretty modest hardware, like a single GPU. It’s different from large-scale models that need massive compute.  And unlike the commercial models, nanoGPT offers a transparent, open-source alternative that breaks down how LLMs work.  It’s a cute little starter kid for GPT models.

title: AI Hallucinations
text:
Hallucinations in AI happens when there are incorrect or misleading results generated by AI models. This happens when an AI system makes false assumptions or uses biased data to generate information.
How do hallucinations happen? > not enough training data > biased training data > wrong assumptions > processing errors
Sometimes, there’s wrong code or images that pop up. It’s up to us to choose whether the information is right or wrong. Let’s look at a few examples that a few people have encountered in the past.  




I took a quick look on Reddit to dig for some examples of ChatGPT hallucinations. I wanted to see if they still existed, since some of the posts were 1-2 years ago.  



Jenn’s update: Well, I think they fixed this up.

Ok, well… let’s check on Reddit for some more ChatGPT hallucinations






Jenn’s update: It’s interesting how they try to reference the information, but still got the information wrong.

Ah-HAH! One down. Let’s try another one. Now, I’m not an organic chemistry person, but let’s see if this one has updated from 2 years ago. ___ #### Organic Chemistry Example 

Jenn’s update: Well, darn! This is sad for any organic chemistry lovers out there. ChatGPT is really bad at organic chemistry.






 Well, it goes to show that ChatGPT, despite its various updates, still manages to get answers wrong and hallucinate. I’m not sure if they’re ever going to be able to turn ChatGPT into an organic chemistry genius or be able to correctly reference sports games. However, it’s interesting to see how certain questions enable incorrect results, and how humans are able to jump in and identify these mistakes.

title: Popular at UPenn: Let’s Test the Range of ChatGPT Tools!
text:
Today as I was thinking about what I should experiment with for my 10th blog post (yay!), I decided to explore my UPenn ChatGPT account that was granted to me by my statistics class.   Tell me why I just discovered a whole section called Explore GPTs. Under the Top Picks section, there’s a section called Popular at Upenn. There’s a whole list of popular GPTs in my workspace which include; Love Run Half-Marathon Training GPT, Interactive Cooking & Recipe Innovator, Rental Analyzer, ConsultingDad.AI, and much more. The list seems infinite! And so niche to a lot of people’s different interests. The more I keep looking, the more my jaw keeps dropping. If I knew about these earlier, I think my life would be easier.



I want to see if they’re actually useful, or if I could just stick to making my own path in life.   Let’s go in order. I’m excited. Let’s go!



(Ask me anything for direction by kawaima@upenn.edu)    I don’t know what they mean by direction. But after I asked, it seems like a tarot card reading situation. I decided to choose tarot because there was a section on career. As of now, I’m still on the job hunt so I am curious to see how this chat box will read my situation >  >     I would say that it’s pretty spot on. I’m pretty sure the creator prompted it with a series of different ones that rotate based on what the user types. Nothing else more to add. Let’s go to the next one.



(This GPT aims to assist runners to succeed in the 2025 Philly Love Run. Whether the runner be a first-timer or looking to get back in shape, this GPT will help design the perfect training plan factoring in wellness, our busy schedules, and fitness goals. By community builder)   This might be the most helpful thing I need right now. I signed up for the Half-Marthon back in December thinking I could prepare for it March 30th. I got sick for a month and that completely messed up my training plan. It’s now almost two weeks before the half, and I have no clue if I can actually do it. Let’s see if GPT can help me out.   >   
Oh well, looks like I’ll be really pushing myself for the next two weeks. I also prompted it to create a calendar version so the information will be easier for me to digest and follow. Look at it below.
